race.name: Lone Wolf Gravel
race.tagline: Upper Peninsula Michigan wilderness gravel in Iron Mountain.

climate.description: Variable conditions. Can be cooler than lower Michigan.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Upper Peninsula wilderness. Rolling to hilly terrain with moderate to significant elevation.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small grassroots Upper Peninsula event. Remote wilderness setting but very limited infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Lone Wolf Gravel is a small grassroots gravel race in Michigan's remote Upper Peninsula. Iron Mountain is slightly more accessible than some UP locations, but it's still remote with minimal amenities and a tiny field. It's an honest local event for hardy Upper Peninsula cyclists who want an affordable wilderness gravel ride.
strengths: More challenging terrain than lower Michigan
weaknesses: Remote Upper Peninsula location (5 hours from Detroit)
Small field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small local gravel race in remote Upper Peninsula. Perfect for locals or those seeking a remote wilderness ride. Not worth the long drive for most riders unless you're combining with Upper Peninsula tourism.

final_verdict.one_liner: Small grassroots Upper Peninsula wilderness ride with remote location.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in the Upper Peninsula or planning UP tourism. Not worth the long drive for the race alone.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Michigan events: Barry-Roubaix, Lumberjack 100. For similar remote wilderness vibes: other Upper Midwest wilderness events.

logistics.airport: Green Bay (GRB) 2 hours, or Detroit (DTW) 5 hours
logistics.lodging_strategy: Iron Mountain has basic lodging. Small city with limited options.
logistics.food: Small city with basic dining. Stock up beforehand.

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in Upper Peninsula.

course_description.character: Rolling to hilly Upper Peninsula wilderness gravel.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling to hilly Upper Peninsula terrain and remote location.

non_negotiables.why: 4000 feet of climbing requires good aerobic capacity.
Remote location and minimal support mean managing your own nutrition and mechanicals.

topics.pacing: Managing effort on rolling to hilly terrain

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of Upper Peninsula wilderness gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Small grassroots event in remote Iron Mountain.

logistics.explanation: Start location coordinates provided (gravel pit off Sportsmens Club Road), but conflicting start times listed - BikeSignup says 9:15 AM while MGRS says 7:00 AM. James Morrow admits timing issues: "we had some disconnects with the manual timing and weren't able to log everyone's times."

length.explanation: The 62-mile distance hits the sweet spot for most gravel riders, with 36, 50, and 100-mile options available. Only one aid station hosted by Embark Maple means self-sufficiency planning is critical for the longer distances. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: James Morrow describes "pristine, hard pack, fast gravel, accompanied by chunky steep, climbs, and rowdy descents." Conditions in 2022 were "pretty dry and loose for gravel biking," suggesting manageable surfaces rather than technical challenges. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 4,000 feet over 62 miles includes what creators call "chunky steep climbs" in Michigan's Upper Peninsula terrain. The elevation profile provides substance without being overwhelming for most gravel riders. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 71°F and lows of 53°F, with a 39% chance of rain on any given day. Race day 2022 delivered "27° in the morning 55° in the afternoon. Partly sunny. Peak color change. A perfect fall day in dah U.P." Late September timing offers spectacular fall colors but requires layering for the temperature swing. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Iron Mountain sits around 1,260 feet above sea level with course elevations staying well below significant altitude thresholds. Altitude is completely irrelevant for performance or acclimatization concerns. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Course creators found the route "while searching to find as much remote gravel as possible" and encountered a gray wolf that gave the race its name. Minimal marking means navigation challenges add uncertainty to the wilderness experience.

prestige.explanation: Dan Teaters is listed as a three-time winner and Andrew Knickerbocker placed 2nd in the 100-mile, but this grassroots event explicitly holds "to the tradition of grass-root origins" rather than pursuing marquee status.

race_quality.explanation: Required course rerouting in year 2 when "Fumee Lake area not allowing their gates to be opened" shows organizational adaptability. Manual timing failures and minimal course marking indicate growing pains in race operations.

experience.explanation: Race proceeds bought "a rescue device for the fire department that will help with single track rescues in the Iron Mountain area." The community-focused approach creates meaning beyond racing, though operational issues affect the participant experience.

community.explanation: Iron Hills Cycling Team promotes "community and support among local residents of Dickinson County" through cycling. 2022 saw "just over 100 registered" with "just under 70 showed up," indicating solid local engagement despite weather concerns.

field_depth.explanation: Small field of under 70 finishers in 2022 consists mainly of regional riders. Dan Teaters' three wins and Mitch Edbauer as a "three-time competitor" represent the competitive ceiling for this grassroots Michigan event. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Race proceeds directly support local fire department equipment purchases, giving entry fees community impact beyond event costs. Three distance options and the grassroots approach provide accessible racing without commercial markup.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-90. Iron Mountain's small-town costs keep lodging and food expenses minimal. Required GPX device and rear flashing light represent the main equipment investments beyond standard gravel gear. Regional location eliminates flight costs for Midwest riders. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

citations.label: thenxrth.com: The Lone Wolf Sequel 2022 Reroutes Peak Colors A Perfect ...

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Episode 95: The Lone Wolf Gravel Race
videos.channel: Dirty Chain Podcast Michigan Midpack Media
videos.description: Race creator, James Morrow, three-time winner, Dan Teaters, and three-time competitor, Mitch Edbauer, join the podcast to share about the Lone Wolf Gravel Race out of Iron Mountain, MI.

varied trails, and then race, ride your
bike on a on a Sunday. Yeah, that sounds
fantastic. Yeah. Thank you guys. Thank
you. uh just for I mean talking about
the race um your experience uh the
tactics which sounded like a lot of fun
and and James thank you for kind of kind
of putting this together putting the
race together and and getting us all in
the same uh Zoom room. Um this is really
cool to hear this story. We were I was
discussing it with my buddy Bruce Lang
and he's like man you know what we
overheard those guys talking about would
make a really good podcast. And I was
like, he goes, "Do you know any?" And I
was like, "Well, kind of know Trevor and
you know, it would kind of be an honor
to to see if you had time and I really
appreciate you getting us on there
because, you know, like I said, this
that story kind of had to be told,
especially this year, um, with what was
going on up front there. It I wish I
could have put a a a water bottle on the
bike to listen to it all going on."
Well, cool. Um, do you guys uh you guys
get on this side of the of the state at
all for any races or you stick mainly in
the up?
Yeah. No, I've been over uh what did I
do? I did uh Barrier Bay last year.
Okay. Um and that was we had some snow
and some pretty inclement weather for
that one. Oh yeah. Um, and uh, but you
know, I I compare that race to to Lone
Wolf and outside of the kind of the same
sharp kind of steep climbs. Um, that
that's like hero dirt over there versus
some of the chunky stuff we we have in
this race. Um, but the level of
competition there is just through the
roof, you know. Um, so yeah, I mean some
of the races down in the the lower lower
side of Michigan, God, I'd love to get
over there and do some of those gravel
races. I wish we had a series like that
here in Wisconsin, but um maybe one day.
Yeah. Yeah. Well, I I'll definitely have
to make my way over on that side. Uh
Mitch, you mentioned uh or to shore. You
do you do or shore or uh Yep. Yep. Done
it a number of years. Yep. managed uh
second single speed this year. So Oh
wow, man. Sounds like Who doesn't do or
to shore? I mean, really. That's true.
If if you're from the Midwest. Yeah,
that's true. That's true. I I love that
race. That's such a good event. Yeah.
Well, so I've done it the last couple
years. And I I'll be there every year if
I can. So hopefully uh hopefully next
year we can uh link up. And what is it?
This little right. Oh, there you go.
Nice.
[Laughter]
Just Yeah, just so you know, for two, I
keep keep her right at the desk.
There it is. 22.
Great guys. I'll let you uh get back to
work unfortunately, but um thanks for
jumping on and telling your story and
yeah, really appreciate it. I appreciate
your time, Trevor. It was fun. Thanks.
Yep. Thanks for having us.
The Dirty Chain podcast is a Michigan
Midpack Media production in partnership
with KM Cycling, the source for your
bike accessories and necessities.
Connect with us on Instagram and
Facebook at
dirtychainodcast. Email dirtychain
podcast@gmail.com. If you are enjoying
the podcast, please leave us a rating
and review on whatever platform you use
to listen. Audio editing and original
music by myself, Trevor Gibney. Thank
you to James and Mitch and Dan for
joining me on this episode and thank you
all for listening to the Dirty Chain
podcast. And as always, keep your chain
clean, but get your chain dirty. We will
see you in the
midpack. You are not alone.

videos.transcript:
It ain't no easy day.
Y'all might not want to hear this,
but it's the truth.
[ __ ] ain't easy. Listen, I'm from where
the steel bones crush your wheel.
Another day, another dollar. Uncle Sam
just got the bill. My brother keeps a
peace. I'm keeping still. So, I'm trying
to run away from trouble. I'm just
keeping still. Here we go. [ __ ] again.
From my dogs and the pain. From the
backwoods to the street blocks to the
highways to the treetops trying to work
through these hard times. I know it's
heavy on your mind, but the real ones
never get tired.
WE ALL NEVER GET TIRED. No
way. Ain't no easy days. I'm ain't no
easy days.
I'm from when it ain't no easy days. I'm
from where ain't no easy days. God
fearing men. I done seen so many
diggers. I can hear from them. I seen
the kids turn to fillings. Make it hard
to trust them. I see my heroes turn to
junkies. Got no fear for them. Trying to
give them hell. Every day I wake up in
the morning. No, I can't fail. Back
against the wall to on the battlefield.
Every single loss is a lesson. Never
take a L.
Never take a nail.
I'm aware it ain't no easy days. I'm
aware it ain't no easy days.
I'm aware it ain't no easy days. No easy
days. I'm ain't no easy day. No
easy day. I'm a word. It ain't no easy
days. No easy day. I'm a word. It ain't
no easy days. No
I'm ain't no easy days. I'm ain't no
I'm ain't no easy days. I'm a easy day.
I'm a easy day. No easy day.

videos.title: IRON CROSS X
videos.description: Highlights from the LWC cam at Iron Cross X. Ten years of the longest cross race in America.

quotes.text: The guys that ride in the Green Bay area often ride together and coordinate training rides, which really does make for a good cycling community. And when you're outnumbered four to one at the start line, you just kind of swallow and say, here we go.
quotes.source_channel: Dirty Chain Podcast Michigan Midpack Media

quotes.text: Part of me still connects more with the smaller local grassroot events that started this whole trend in the first place. Races like the lone wolf.
quotes.source_channel: Dirty Chain Podcast Michigan Midpack Media

rider_intel.search_text: The provided transcripts do not contain any race-related content for the Lone Wolf Gravel race in Iron Mountain, Michigan. The transcripts appear to be music videos or songs rather than race reports or rider experiences. No information about course features, terrain conditions, challenges, gear recommendations, or race atmosphere is available from these sources.

photos.alt: Group of gravel cyclists in racing formation riding on dirt road through autumn countryside during Lone Wolf gravel race - Iron Mountain, Michigan
photos.credit: YouTube / Dirty Chain Podcast Michigan Midpack Media

photos.alt: Cyclists riding through wooded gravel trail with dappled sunlight filtering through tree canopy overhead - Lone Wolf Gravel - Iron Mountain, Michigan
photos.credit: YouTube / Dirty Chain Podcast Michigan Midpack Media

photos.credit: YouTube / Dirty Chain Podcast Michigan Midpack Media
